</EFX_FINANCIAL_DATA>
<EFX_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION>
<A NAME="FIS_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<A NAME="D293667D10K_HTM_TX293667_11">
</A>
	ITEM&nbsp;7. MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND
	RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following discussion is an analysis of our results of operations for the fiscal years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015,
	and 2014, and financial condition as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015. This discussion and analysis should be read in conjunction with our consolidated financial statements and related notes. This discussion contains forward-looking statements
	concerning our business. Readers are cautioned that, by their nature, forward-looking statements are based on estimates and assumptions and are subject to risks, uncertainties, and other factors. Actual results may differ materially from our
	expectations that are expressed or implied by any forward-looking statement. The discussion in Item 1A, &#147;Risk Factors,&#148; lists some of the factors that could cause our actual results to vary materially from those expressed or implied by any
	forward-looking statements, and such discussion is incorporated into this discussion by reference.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	GENERAL OVERVIEW
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Old National is the largest financial holding company incorporated in the state of Indiana and maintains its principal executive offices in Evansville,
	Indiana. Old National, through Old National Bank, provides a wide range of services, including commercial and consumer loan and depository services, and other traditional banking services. Old National also provides services to supplement the
	traditional banking business including fiduciary and wealth management services, investment and brokerage services, investment consulting, and other financial services.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our basic mission is to be THE community bank in the cities and towns we serve. We focus on establishing and maintaining long-term relationships with
	customers, and are committed to serving the financial needs of the communities in our market area. Old National provides financial services primarily in Indiana, Kentucky, Michigan, and Wisconsin.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	CORPORATE DEVELOPMENTS IN FISCAL 2016
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2016, we
	expanded our footprint into the state of Wisconsin through our acquisition of Anchor BanCorp Wisconsin Inc. (&#147;Anchor&#148;). In addition to our entry into this vibrant new market, management remained keenly focused on organic growth and
	efficiency efforts. This is evidenced by the following 2016 initiatives:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	organic loan growth of over 7% (including loans held for sale);
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	the sale of our insurance subsidiary and the redeployment of capital into our higher yielding banking business;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	the termination of our frozen pension plan, which will eliminate future annual expense associated with the plan;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	the termination of our labor-intensive loss share agreements with the FDIC at a minimal financial impact; and
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	on-going
</FONT>
	assessment of our service and delivery network, resulting in the consolidation of five banking centers in 2016 and fifteen additional banking centers in January 2017.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Total revenues increased to $655.5&nbsp;million, or 10%, from $596.7&nbsp;million in 2015 and noninterest expenses remained well
	controlled, increasing to $454.1&nbsp;million, or 5%, from $430.9&nbsp;million in 2015. Net income for 2016 was $134.3&nbsp;million, which compares favorably to 2015 net income of $116.7&nbsp;million. Diluted earnings per share were $1.05 per share
	in 2016, compared to $1.00 per share in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	BUSINESS OUTLOOK
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Post-election, equity prices have surged and there is optimism that several policy changes will boost GDP growth. While it is yet to be seen if these proposals
	will pass and if they will truly benefit United States business, there appears to be rising consumer confidence. If our commercial loan pipeline is at all predictive, it appears that companies may be coming off the sidelines, and we may see an
	uptick in business investment during 2017.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Old National, along with all financial institutions, is also watching interest rates closely, and is
	encouraged by the 25 basis-point rate increase at the end of 2016. Additional rate increases in 2017 will benefit Old National as our assets tend to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	re-price
</FONT>
	faster and with more margin than our liabilities.
	In addition, Old National&#146;s dominant market share in many of the communities in which we serve will become more valuable as deposits typically cost less than other types of funding.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	30
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage31"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D293667D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our focus for 2017 will be much like our focus in 2016, as we execute on our revenue growth and expense
	management strategy. We have transitioned our footprint into higher growth markets and opportunistically will continue to do so. We believe we have the right people and the right products in the right markets, with strong leadership in place. Core
	revenue growth, improvement in our operating leverage, and the prudent use of capital will remain priorities.
</P>

</TD>

<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:8.0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PT;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000;WIDTH:10%">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Efficiency ratio is defined as noninterest expense before amortization of intangibles as a percent of fully taxable net interest income and noninterest income, excluding net gains from securities transactions. This
	presentation excludes intangible amortization and net securities gains, as is common in other company disclosures, and better aligns with true operating performance. This is a non-GAAP financial measure that management believes to be helpful in
	understanding Old National&#146;s results of operations.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Comparison of Fiscal Years 2016 and 2015
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Net Interest Income
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net interest income is the most
	significant component of our earnings, comprising 61% of 2016 revenues. Net interest income and margin are influenced by many factors, primarily the volume and mix of earning assets, funding sources, and interest rate fluctuations. Other factors
	include the level of accretion income on purchased loans, prepayment risk on mortgage and investment-related assets, and the composition and maturity of earning assets and interest-bearing liabilities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Interest rates increased in the fourth quarter 2016, driven by improving economic conditions evidenced by the Federal Reserve increasing the discount rate 25
	basis points at their December meeting. The yield curve steepened as the spread between short and longer duration Treasuries widened. These factors improve the outlook for our net interest income and margin.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Loans typically generate more interest income than investment securities with similar maturities. Funding from client deposits generally costs less than
	wholesale funding sources. Factors such as general economic activity, Federal Reserve Board monetary policy, and price volatility of competing alternative investments, can also exert significant influence on our ability to optimize the mix of assets
	and funding and the net interest income and margin.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net interest income is the excess of interest received from earning assets over interest paid on
	interest-bearing liabilities. For analytical purposes, net interest income is also presented in the table that follows, adjusted to a taxable equivalent basis to reflect what our
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	tax-exempt
</FONT>
	assets would need
	to yield in order to achieve the same
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	after-tax
</FONT>
	yield as a taxable asset. We used the federal statutory tax rate in effect of 35% for all periods adjusted for the TEFRA interest disallowance applicable to
	certain
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	tax-exempt
</FONT>
	obligations. This analysis portrays the income tax benefits associated in
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	tax-exempt
</FONT>
	assets and helps to facilitate a comparison between taxable and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	tax-exempt
</FONT>
	assets.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	31
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage32"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D293667D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Management believes that it is a standard practice in the banking industry to present net interest margin and net interest income on a fully taxable equivalent basis. Therefore, management
	believes these measures provide useful information for both management and investors by allowing them to make peer comparisons.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

	4.22
</TD>

	%&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net interest income was $402.7&nbsp;million in 2016, a $36.6&nbsp;million increase from $366.1&nbsp;million in 2015. Taxable
	equivalent net interest income was $424.0&nbsp;million in 2016, a 10% increase from $385.7&nbsp;million in 2015. The net interest margin on a fully taxable equivalent basis was 3.58% in 2016, a 14 basis point decrease compared to 3.72% in 2015. Both
	2016 and 2015 included accretion income (interest income in excess of contractual interest income) associated with acquired loans. Excluding this accretion income in both periods, net interest income on a fully taxable equivalent basis would have
	been $365.9&nbsp;million in 2016 compared to $322.6&nbsp;million in 2015; and the net interest margin on a fully taxable equivalent basis would have been 3.09% in 2016 and 3.11% in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The increase in net interest income in 2016 when compared to 2015 was primarily due to an increase in average earning assets of $1.478&nbsp;billion in 2016.
	Partially offsetting the higher average earning assets was a decrease in accretion income of $5.0&nbsp;million. We expect accretion income on our purchased credit impaired loans to decrease over time, but this may be offset by future acquisitions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following table presents a three-year average balance sheet and for each major asset and liability category, its related interest income and yield,
	or its expense and rate for the years ended December 31.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	32
</P>

<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	The 2016, 2015, and 2014 average balances include $24.8 million, $35.2 million, and $12.3 million, respectively, of required and excess balances held at the Federal Reserve.
</TD>

</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

	(2)
</TD>

	Changes in fair value are reflected in the average balance; however, yield information does not give effect to changes in fair value that are reflected as a component of shareholders&#146; equity.
</TD>
</TR>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

</TD>

</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(4)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Interest on state and political subdivision investment securities and commercial loans includes the effect of taxable equivalent adjustments of $15.2 million and $6.1 million, respectively, in 2016; $13.7 million and
	$5.9 million, respectively, in 2015; and $11.8 million and $5.2 million, respectively, in 2014; using the federal statutory tax rate in effect of 35% for all periods adjusted for the TEFRA interest disallowance applicable to certain tax-exempt
	obligations.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	33
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage34"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D293667D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The yield on average earning assets decreased 8 basis points from 4.04% in 2015 to 3.96% in 2016 and the cost of
	interest-bearing liabilities increased 7 basis points from 0.43% in 2015 to 0.50% in 2016. Average earning assets increased by $1.478&nbsp;billion, or 14%. The increase in average earning assets consisted of a $1.391&nbsp;billion increase in loans,
	a $97.2&nbsp;million increase in lower yielding investment securities, partially offset by a $10.7&nbsp;million decrease in money market and other interest-earning investments. Average interest-bearing liabilities increased $1.217&nbsp;billion, or
	16%. The increase in average interest-bearing liabilities consisted of a $909.7&nbsp;million increase in interest-bearing deposits, an $11.9&nbsp;million increase in federal funds purchased and interbank borrowings, a $37.4&nbsp;million decrease in
	securities sold under agreements to repurchase, a $327.7&nbsp;million increase in Federal Home Loan Bank advances, and a $4.7&nbsp;million increase in other borrowings. Average noninterest-bearing deposits increased by $275.6&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The increase in average earning assets in 2016 compared to 2015 was primarily due to our acquisition of Anchor in May 2016. Including loans held for sale, the
	loan portfolio, which generally has an average yield higher than the investment portfolio, was approximately 70% of average interest earning assets in 2016 compared to 66% in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Average loans including loans held for sale increased $1.391&nbsp;billion in 2016 compared to 2015 reflecting $1.152&nbsp;billion of average loans acquired
	from Anchor in May 2016, along with $239.2&nbsp;million of organic loan growth. These increases were partially offset by the sale of $193.6&nbsp;million of loans associated with our branch divestitures during the third quarter of 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The increases in average investments and average deposits also reflected the Anchor acquisition.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Average
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-interest
</FONT>
	bearing deposits increased $275.6&nbsp;million in 2016 compared to 2015 reflecting
	$241.8&nbsp;million of average
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-interest
</FONT>
	bearing deposits from the Anchor acquisition. Average interest bearing deposits increased $909.7&nbsp;million in 2016 compared to 2015 reflecting $963.6&nbsp;million
	of average interest bearing deposits from the Anchor acquisition. These increases were partially offset by a $555.8&nbsp;million reduction associated with our branch divestitures during the third quarter of 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Average borrowed funds increased $307.0&nbsp;million in 2016 compared to 2015 primarily due to increased funding needed as a result of growth in our
	investment and loan portfolios that outpaced deposit growth.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	34
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The variance not solely due to rate or volume is allocated equally between the rate and volume variances.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Interest on investment securities and loans includes the effect of taxable equivalent adjustments of $15.2 million and $6.2 million, respectively, in 2016; $13.7 million and $5.9 million, respectively, in 2015; and
	$11.8 million and $5.2 million, respectively, in 2014; using the federal statutory rate in effect of 35% for all periods adjusted for the TEFRA
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	interest disallowance applicable to certain tax-exempt obligations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Provision for Loan Losses
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The provision for loan losses
	was an expense of $1.0&nbsp;million in 2016, compared to an expense of $2.9&nbsp;million in 2015. Net charge-offs totaled $3.4&nbsp;million in 2016, compared to net recoveries of $1.5&nbsp;million in 2015. The lower provision for loan losses is the
	result of the increase in purchased loans that were recorded at fair value and improved asset quality. The fair value adjustment considers credit impairment resulting in no need for an allowance for loan losses at the date of acquisition. Continued
	loan growth in future periods, or a decline in our current level of recoveries, could result in an increase in provision expense. For additional information about
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-performing
</FONT>
	loans, charge-offs, and
	additional items impacting the provision, refer to the &#147;Risk Management&#151;Credit Risk&#148; section of Item 7, &#147;Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations&#148;.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Noninterest Income
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We generate revenues in the form of
	noninterest income through client fees, sales commissions, and other gains and losses from our core banking franchise and other related businesses, such as wealth management, investment consulting, and investment products. This source of revenue as
	a percentage of total revenue was 39% in 2016 and 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Noninterest income was $252.8&nbsp;million in 2016, an increase of $22.2&nbsp;million, or 10%,
	compared to $230.6&nbsp;million in 2015. The increase in noninterest income in 2016 was primarily due to a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-tax
</FONT>
	gain of $41.9&nbsp;million resulting from the sale of ONB Insurance Group, Inc.
	(&#147;ONI&#148;) in May 2016 and noninterest income attributable to the Anchor acquisition. The increase in noninterest income was partially offset by a $15.6&nbsp;million gain on branch divestitures in the third quarter of 2015 and lower insurance
	premiums and commissions resulting from the sale on ONI.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	35
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage36"></A>

<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:8.0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PT;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000;WIDTH:10%">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Total revenue includes the effect of a taxable equivalent adjustment of $21.3 million in 2016, $19.5 million
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	in 2015, and $17.0 million in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	N/M = Not
	meaningful
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Service charges and overdraft fees on deposit accounts continued to be challenged. The divestiture of the southern Illinois region during the
	third quarter of 2015 also contributed to the decrease in service charges and overdraft fees on deposit accounts year over year. These decreases were partially offset by $3.7&nbsp;million of service charges and overdraft fees attributable to the
	Anchor acquisition.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Debit card and ATM fees decreased $4.6&nbsp;million in 2016 compared to 2015 as the Durbin Amendment, which limits interchange fees
	on debit card transactions for banks with $10&nbsp;billion or more in assets, became effective for us on July&nbsp;1, 2015. The decrease in debit card and ATM fees was partially offset by $1.7&nbsp;million of debit card and ATM fees attributable to
	the Anchor acquisition.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Mortgage banking revenue increased $7.7&nbsp;million to $20.2&nbsp;million in 2016 compared to $12.5&nbsp;million in 2015
	primarily due to increased sales to the secondary market in 2016 and an increase in production largely attributable to our new associates in the Wisconsin region.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Insurance premiums and commissions decreased $22.2&nbsp;million in 2016 reflecting the sale of ONI in May 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2016, we recorded a $41.9&nbsp;million
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-tax
</FONT>
	gain resulting from the sale of ONI in May 2016. The
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	after-tax
</FONT>
	gain related to the sale totaled $17.6&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2015, we recorded a net gain of $15.6&nbsp;million in
	connection with the August 2015 divestitures of our southern Illinois region (twelve branches) along with four branches in eastern Indiana and one in Ohio.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Other income increased $6.8&nbsp;million in 2016 compared to 2015. Included in 2016 was $7.6&nbsp;million of recoveries on Anchor loans that had been fully
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	charged-off
</FONT>
	prior to the acquisition.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Noninterest Income Related to Covered Assets and Indemnification Asset
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2011, Old National acquired the banking operations of Integra Bank N.A. in an FDIC-assisted transaction. The FDIC had agreed to reimburse Old
	National for losses incurred on certain acquired loans, and we recorded an indemnification asset at fair value on the date that we acquired these loans. The indemnification asset, on the
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	36
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage37"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D293667D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	acquisition date, reflected the reimbursements expected to be received from the FDIC. Deterioration in the expected credit quality of both OREO and loans increased the basis of the
	indemnification asset. The offset for both OREO and loans was recorded through the consolidated statement of income. Increases in the credit quality or cash flows of loans (reflected as an adjustment to yield and accreted into income over the
	remaining life of the loans) decreased the basis of the indemnification asset, with the decrease being amortized into income over the same period or the life of the loss share agreements, whichever was shorter.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Old National entered into an agreement with the FDIC on June&nbsp;22, 2016 to terminate its loss share agreements. Under the early termination agreement, the
	FDIC made a final payment of $8.7&nbsp;million to Old National as consideration for the early termination. After the elimination of the remaining FDIC indemnification asset and the payment of settlement charges, Old National realized a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-tax
</FONT>
	gain of $0.2&nbsp;million during 2016. All remaining assets that were covered by the loss share arrangements were reclassified to noncovered assets effective June&nbsp;22, 2016. All future gains and losses
	associated with covered assets will be recognized entirely by Old National.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Noninterest Expense
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Noninterest expense totaled $454.1&nbsp;million in 2016, an increase of $23.2&nbsp;million, or 5%, from $430.9&nbsp;million in 2015. Noninterest expense during
	2016 was impacted by our transition into the higher growth markets in Wisconsin, the divestitures of our Illinois franchise and our insurance business, and other branch restructuring during 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following table details the components of noninterest expense for the years ended December 31.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Salaries and benefits, the largest component of noninterest expense, totaled $252.9&nbsp;million in 2016, compared to
	$243.9&nbsp;million in 2015, an increase of $9.0&nbsp;million, or 4%. Impacting salaries and benefits expense were the acquisition of Anchor and the divestitures described above. Also contributing to the increase in salaries and benefits was a
	pension plan settlement loss of $9.8&nbsp;million resulting from the termination of the Employee Retirement Plan. The increase was partially offset by a higher level of severance expense in 2015 related to early retirement offers and other workforce
	reductions along with lower incentive bonus accruals in 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Occupancy expenses decreased $2.3&nbsp;million to $50.9&nbsp;million in 2016 compared to
	2015 primarily due to branch divestures and consolidations in the third quarter of 2015. The decrease was partially offset by occupancy expenses attributable to the Anchor acquisition.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Marketing expense increased $4.2&nbsp;million in 2016 compared to 2015 primarily due to additional expenses recorded in 2016 associated with the Anchor
	acquisition, higher advertising, and public relations expense.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	37
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage38"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D293667D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Data processing expense increased $4.7&nbsp;million in 2016 compared to 2015 primarily due the systems conversion
	associated with the Anchor acquisition.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Professional fees increased $3.9&nbsp;million in 2016 compared to 2015 primarily due additional expenses recorded
	in 2016 associated with the Anchor acquisition.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Other expense was $28.7&nbsp;million in 2016 compared to $31.0&nbsp;million in 2015. Included in other
	expense in 2016 were $4.8&nbsp;million of costs related to the consolidation of fifteen banking centers in January 2017, Anchor acquisition and integration costs of $2.4&nbsp;million, and higher charitable contributions of $2.1&nbsp;million when
	compared to 2015. Included in other expense in 2015 were costs associated with branch divestitures, closures, and consolidations totaling $7.8&nbsp;million and a $4.8&nbsp;million legal settlement accrual.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Provision for Income Taxes
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We record a provision for
	income taxes currently payable and for income taxes payable or benefits to be received in the future, which arise due to timing differences in the recognition of certain items for financial statement and income tax purposes. The major difference
	between the effective tax rate applied to our financial statement income and the federal statutory tax rate is caused by interest on
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	tax-exempt
</FONT>
	securities and loans. The effective tax rate was 33.0% in 2016
	compared to 28.3% in 2015. The higher effective tax rate in 2016 when compared to 2015 is primarily the result of the sale of ONI in May 2016 and the associated tax expense of $8.3&nbsp;million to record a deferred tax liability relating to
	ONI&#146;s nondeductible goodwill. See Note 17 to the consolidated financial statements for additional details on Old National&#146;s income tax provision.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Comparison of Fiscal Years 2015 and 2014
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2015,
	we generated net income of $116.7&nbsp;million and diluted net income per share of $1.00 compared to $103.7&nbsp;million and diluted net income per share of $0.95, respectively, in 2014. The 2015 earnings included a $0.2&nbsp;million decrease in
	provision for loan losses and a $65.5&nbsp;million increase in noninterest income. These increases to net income were partially offset by a $0.3&nbsp;million decrease in net interest income, a $44.5&nbsp;million increase in noninterest expense, and
	a $7.9&nbsp;million increase in income tax expense.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net interest income was $366.1&nbsp;million in 2015, a $0.3&nbsp;million decrease from
	$366.4&nbsp;million in 2014. Taxable equivalent net interest income was $385.7&nbsp;million in 2015, a 1% increase from $383.4&nbsp;million in 2014. The net interest margin on a fully taxable equivalent basis was 3.72% in 2015, a 50 basis point
	decrease compared to 4.22% in 2014. Average earning assets increased by $1.280&nbsp;billion during 2015 and the yield on average earning assets decreased 44 basis points from 4.48% in 2014 to 4.04% in 2015. Average interest-bearing liabilities
	increased $977.7&nbsp;million and the cost of interest-bearing liabilities increased from 0.35% to 0.43% in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The provision for loan losses was an
	expense of $2.9&nbsp;million in 2015, compared to an expense of $3.1&nbsp;million in 2014. Charge-offs remained low during 2015 and we continued to see positive trends in credit quality.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Noninterest income was $230.6&nbsp;million in 2015, an increase of $65.5&nbsp;million, or 40%, compared to $165.1&nbsp;million in 2014. The increase in
	noninterest income in 2015 was primarily due to a negative adjustment of $9.0&nbsp;million for the FDIC indemnification asset in 2015 compared to a negative adjustment of $43.2&nbsp;million for the FDIC indemnification asset in 2014. The increase
	was also due to acquisitions during 2014 and 2015, a $15.6&nbsp;million gain on branch divestitures in 2015, and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-tax
</FONT>
	deferred gains of $10.8&nbsp;million resulting from the acquisition of fourteen bank
	properties that Old National had previously leased.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Noninterest expense totaled $430.9&nbsp;million in 2015, an increase of $44.5&nbsp;million, or 12%,
	from $386.4&nbsp;million in 2014. The increase was primarily due to higher salaries and benefits, other expense, occupancy expenses, and amortization of intangibles. These increases were partially offset by lower acquisition and integration costs.
	Operating expenses associated with the acquisitions of Tower, United, LSB, and Founders totaled $39.0&nbsp;million in 2015 compared to $18.5&nbsp;million in 2014. In addition, noninterest expense also included acquisition and integration costs
	associated with these transactions totaling $5.7&nbsp;million in 2015 compared to $15.6&nbsp;million in 2014. Noninterest expense in 2015 also included costs associated with branch divestitures, closures, and consolidations totaling
	$9.5&nbsp;million, $5.6&nbsp;million of severance expense related to early retirement offers and other workforce reductions, and a $4.8&nbsp;million legal settlement accrual.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	38
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage39"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D293667D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The provision for income taxes was $46.2&nbsp;million in 2015 compared to $38.3&nbsp;million in 2014. Old
	National&#146;s effective tax rate was 28.3% in 2015 compared to 27.0% in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	FINANCIAL CONDITION
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Overview
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2016, our assets were
	$14.860&nbsp;billion, a 24% increase compared to $11.992&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2015. The increase was primarily due to the acquisition of Anchor in May 2016, which had $2.166&nbsp;billion in assets as of the closing date of the
	acquisition.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Earning Assets
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Earning assets,
	comprised of investment securities, portfolio loans, loans held for sale, money market investments, interest earning accounts with the Federal Reserve, and trading securities, were $12.796&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2016, an increase of 22%
	compared to $10.471&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Investment Securities
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We classify the majority of our investment securities as
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	available-for-sale
</FONT>
</FONT>
	to
	give management the flexibility to sell the securities prior to maturity if needed, based on fluctuating interest rates or changes in our funding requirements. However, we also have $10.6&nbsp;million of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	15-
</FONT>
	and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	20-year
</FONT>
	fixed-rate mortgage-backed securities, $40.1&nbsp;million of U.S. government-sponsored entity and agency securities, and $694.3&nbsp;million of state and political subdivision securities in our
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	held-to-maturity
</FONT>
</FONT>
	investment portfolio at December&nbsp;31, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Trading
	securities, which consist of mutual funds held in trusts associated with deferred compensation plans for former directors and executives, are recorded at fair value and totaled $5.0&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2016 compared to
	$3.9&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015. The increase was primarily due to the acquisition of Anchor, which had $0.9&nbsp;million in trading securities as of the closing date of the acquisition.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2016, the investment securities portfolio, including trading securities, was $3.649&nbsp;billion compared to $3.380&nbsp;billion at
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, an increase of $268.5&nbsp;million, or 8%. Investment securities attributable to the Anchor acquisition totaled $239.8&nbsp;million as of the closing date of the acquisition. Investment securities represented 29% of earning
	assets at December&nbsp;31, 2016, compared to 32% at December&nbsp;31, 2015. Investment securities also decreased as a percentage of total earning assets due to a proportionately larger increase in loan balances. Stronger commercial loan demand in
	the future and management&#146;s decision to deleverage the balance sheet could result in a reduction in the securities portfolio. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, management does not intend to sell any securities in an unrealized loss position and
	does not believe we will be required to sell such securities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The investment securities
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	available-for-sale
</FONT>
</FONT>
	portfolio had net unrealized losses of $61.5&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2016, compared to net unrealized losses of $5.8&nbsp;million at
	December&nbsp;31, 2015. Net unrealized losses increased from December&nbsp;31, 2015 to December&nbsp;31, 2016 primarily due to an increase in long-term interest rates on municipal bonds and mortgage-backed securities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The investment portfolio had an effective duration of 4.61 at December&nbsp;31, 2016, compared 3.99 at December&nbsp;31, 2015. Effective duration measures the
	percentage change in value of the portfolio in response to a change in interest rates. Generally, there is more uncertainty in interest rates over a longer average maturity, resulting in a higher duration percentage. The weighted average yields on
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	available-for-sale
</FONT>
</FONT>
	investment securities were 2.44% in 2016 and 2.38% in 2015. The average yields on the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	held-to-maturity
</FONT>
</FONT>
	portfolio were 5.35% in 2016 and 4.99% in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	At
	December&nbsp;31, 2016, Old National had a concentration of investment securities issued by certain states and their political subdivisions with the following aggregate market values: $369.4&nbsp;million by Indiana, which represented 20.4% of
	shareholders&#146; equity, and $198.2&nbsp;million by Texas, which represented 10.9% of shareholders&#146; equity. Of the Indiana municipal bonds, 97% are rated &#147;A&#148; or better, and the remaining 3% generally represent
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-rated
</FONT>
	local interest bonds where Old National has a market presence. All of the Texas municipal bonds are rated &#147;AA&#148; or better, and the majority of issues are backed by the &#147;AAA&#148; rated State
	of Texas Permanent School Fund Guarantee Program.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	39
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage40"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D293667D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Loan Portfolio
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We lend primarily to consumers and small to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	medium-sized
</FONT>
	commercial and commercial real estate clients in various
	industries including manufacturing, agribusiness, transportation, mining, wholesaling, and retailing. Our policy is to concentrate our lending activity in the geographic market areas we serve, primarily Indiana, Kentucky, Michigan, and Wisconsin.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following table presents the composition of the loan portfolio at December 31.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Commercial and Commercial Real Estate Loans
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2016, commercial and commercial real estate loans were $5.048&nbsp;billion, an increase of $1.364&nbsp;billion, or 37%, compared to
	December&nbsp;31, 2015. Commercial and commercial real estate loans attributable to the Anchor acquisition totaled $968.6&nbsp;million as of the closing date of the acquisition.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following table presents the maturity distribution and rate sensitivity of commercial loans at December&nbsp;31, 2016 and an analysis of these loans that
	have predetermined and floating interest rates. A significant percentage of commercial loans are due within one year, reflecting the short-term nature of a large portion of these loans.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Residential Real Estate Loans
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Residential real estate loans, primarily
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	1-4
</FONT>
	family properties, increased $426.2&nbsp;million, or 26%, at
	December&nbsp;31, 2016 compared to December&nbsp;31, 2015. Residential real estate loans attributable to the Anchor acquisition totaled $456.1&nbsp;million as of the closing date of the acquisition. Future increases in interest rates could result in
	a decline in the level of refinancings and new originations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Consumer Loans
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Consumer loans, including automobile loans, personal and home equity loans and lines of credit, and student loans, increased $271.9&nbsp;million, or 17%, at
	December&nbsp;31, 2016 compared to December&nbsp;31, 2015. Consumer loans attributable to the Anchor acquisition totaled $213.0&nbsp;million as of the closing date of the acquisition. Management plans to slow indirect consumer loan originations,
	which are least profitable, in 2017.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	40
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage41"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D293667D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Allowance for Loan Losses
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	To provide for the risk of loss inherent in extending credit, we maintain an allowance for loan losses. The determination of the allowance is based upon the
	size and current risk characteristics of the loan portfolio and includes an assessment of individual problem loans, actual loss experience, current economic events, and regulatory guidance. Additional information about our Allowance for Loan Losses
	is included in the &#147;Risk Management&nbsp;-&nbsp;Credit Risk&#148; section of Item 7, &#147;Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations&#148; and Notes 1 and 6 to the consolidated financial
	statements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2016, the allowance for loan losses was $49.8&nbsp;million, a decrease of $2.4&nbsp;million compared to
	$52.2&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015. Continued loan growth in future periods, or a decline in our current level of recoveries, could result in an increase in provision expense. As a percentage of total loans excluding loans held for sale,
	the allowance was 0.55% at December&nbsp;31, 2016, compared to 0.75% at December&nbsp;31, 2015. The decrease in the percentage from December&nbsp;31, 2015 is primarily a result of the addition of Anchor&#146;s $1.638&nbsp;billion loan portfolio. In
	accordance with ASC 805, no allowance for loan losses is recorded at the date of acquisition and a reserve is only established to absorb any subsequent credit deterioration or adverse changes in expected cash flows. The provision for loan losses was
	an expense of $1.0&nbsp;million in 2016 compared to an expense of $2.9&nbsp;million in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For commercial loans, the allowance for loan losses
	decreased by $4.1&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2016 compared to December&nbsp;31, 2015. The allowance for loan losses as a percentage of the commercial loan portfolio decreased to 1.12% at December&nbsp;31, 2016, from 1.45% at December&nbsp;31,
	2015. The lower allowance for loan losses as a percentage of the commercial loan portfolio is the result of lower loss ratios and a change in the mix between acquired and originated loans.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For commercial real estate loans, the allowance for loan losses increased by $2.2&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2016 compared to December&nbsp;31, 2015.
	The allowance for loan losses as a percentage of the commercial real estate loan portfolio decreased to 0.58% at December&nbsp;31, 2016, from 0.86% at December&nbsp;31, 2015. The lower allowance for loan losses need is the result of the increase in
	purchased loans that were recorded at fair value and improved asset quality. The fair value adjustment considers credit impairment resulting in no need for an allowance for loan losses at the date of acquisition. An allowance may be recorded in
	future periods if the loan experiences subsequent deterioration. See the discussion in the section &#147;Asset Quality&#148; for additional details.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The
	allowance for loan losses for residential real estate loans as a percentage of that portfolio decreased to 0.08% at December&nbsp;31, 2016, from 0.12% at December&nbsp;31, 2015. The allowance for loan losses for consumer loans as a percentage of
	that portfolio decreased to 0.45% at December&nbsp;31, 2016, from 0.49% at December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Allowance for Losses on Unfunded Commitments
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We maintain an allowance for losses on unfunded commercial lending commitments and letters of credit to provide for the risk of loss inherent in these
	arrangements. The allowance is computed using a methodology similar to that used to determine the allowance for loan losses, modified to take into account the probability of a drawdown on the commitment. This allowance is reported as a liability on
	the balance sheet within accrued expenses and other liabilities, while the corresponding provision for these loan losses is recorded as a component of other expense. The allowance for losses on unfunded commitments was $3.2&nbsp;million at
	December&nbsp;31, 2016, compared to $3.6&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Loans Held for Sale
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Mortgage loans held for immediate sale in the secondary market were $90.7&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2016, compared to $13.8&nbsp;million at
	December&nbsp;31, 2015. Certain mortgage loans are committed for sale at or prior to origination at a contracted price to an outside investor. Other mortgage loans held for immediate sale are hedged with To Be Announced (&#147;TBA&#148;) forward
	agreements and committed for sale when they are ready for delivery and remain on the Company&#146;s balance sheet for a short period of time (typically 30 to 60 days). These loans are sold without recourse, beyond customary representations and
	warranties, and Old National has not experienced material losses arising from these sales. Mortgage originations are subject to volatility due to interest rates and home sales, among other factors.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	41
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage42"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D293667D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We have elected the fair value option under FASB ASC
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	825-10
</FONT>
	(SFAS
	No.&nbsp;159) prospectively for residential loans held for sale. The aggregate fair value exceeded the unpaid principal balance by $0.1&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2016, compared to $0.2&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the fourth quarter of 2014, $197.9&nbsp;million of loans were reclassified to loans held for sale at the lower of cost or fair value. When the branch
	divestitures closed during the third quarter of 2015, these loans were valued at $193.6&nbsp;million, resulting in a gain of $0.1&nbsp;million. At December&nbsp;31, 2016, there were no loans held for sale under this arrangement. See Note 2 to the
	consolidated financial statements for additional information.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Covered Assets
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On July&nbsp;29, 2011, Old National acquired the banking operations of Integra in an FDIC assisted transaction. We entered into separate loss sharing
	agreements with the FDIC providing for specified credit loss protection for substantially all acquired single family residential loans, commercial loans, and OREO. Old National entered into an agreement with the FDIC on June&nbsp;22, 2016 to
	terminate its loss share agreements. Under the early termination agreement, the FDIC made a final payment of $8.7&nbsp;million to Old National as consideration for the early termination. After the elimination of the remaining FDIC indemnification
	asset and the payment of settlement charges, Old National realized a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-tax
</FONT>
	gain of $0.2&nbsp;million during the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2016. All remaining assets that were covered by the loss share
	arrangements were reclassified to noncovered assets effective June&nbsp;22, 2016. All future gains and losses associated with covered assets will be recognized entirely by Old National.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Premises and Equipment
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Premises and equipment, net of
	accumulated depreciation increased $232.9&nbsp;million since December&nbsp;31, 2015. During 2016, the Company purchased certain bank properties that it had previously leased, including its executive offices, for an aggregate purchase price of
	$196.1&nbsp;million. Premises and equipment attributable to the Anchor acquisition totaled $35.7&nbsp;million as of the closing date of the acquisition.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Goodwill and other
	intangible assets at December&nbsp;31, 2016 totaled $692.7&nbsp;million, an increase of $72.8&nbsp;million compared to $619.9&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015. During 2016, we recorded $132.9&nbsp;million of goodwill and other intangible
	assets associated with the acquisition of Anchor. Also during 2016, Old National eliminated $47.7&nbsp;million of goodwill and intangible assets associated with the sale of its insurance operations. Total amortization expense associated with
	intangible assets was $12.5&nbsp;million in 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Net Deferred Tax Assets
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net deferred tax assets increased $71.9&nbsp;million since December&nbsp;31, 2015 primarily due to the acquisition of Anchor. Net deferred tax assets acquired
	from Anchor totaled $98.1&nbsp;million, consisting primarily of deferred tax assets related to federal and state net operating loss carryforwards and acquired loans. Future decreases in the corporate tax rate could result in a loss in value of Old
	National&#146;s deferred tax assets, but would reduce future income tax expense. See Note 17 to the consolidated financial statements for additional information.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Other Assets
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Other assets increased $9.1&nbsp;million,
	or 9%, since December&nbsp;31, 2015 primarily due to an increase in low income housing partnership investments. Offsetting the increase were lower deferred rent payments resulting from the purchase of certain bank properties that were previously
	leased and lower receivables resulting from the divestiture of our insurance operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	42
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage43"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D293667D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Funding
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Total funding, comprised of deposits and wholesale borrowings, was $12.895&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2016, an increase of $2.574&nbsp;billion from
	$10.321&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2015. Total deposits were $10.743&nbsp;billion, including $9.275&nbsp;billion in transaction accounts and $1.468&nbsp;billion in time deposits at December&nbsp;31, 2016. Total deposits increased
	$2.342&nbsp;billion, or 28%, compared to December&nbsp;31, 2015. Deposits attributable to the Anchor acquisition totaled $1.853&nbsp;billion as of the closing date of the acquisition. Noninterest-bearing demand deposits increased $527.2&nbsp;million
	from December&nbsp;31, 2015 to December&nbsp;31, 2016. NOW deposits increased $463.1&nbsp;million from December&nbsp;31, 2015 to December&nbsp;31, 2016, while savings deposits increased $753.4&nbsp;million. Money market deposits increased
	$130.7&nbsp;million from December&nbsp;31, 2015 to December&nbsp;31, 2016, while time deposits increased $468.0&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We use wholesale funding to
	augment deposit funding and to help maintain our desired interest rate risk position. At December&nbsp;31, 2016, wholesale borrowings, including federal funds purchased and interbank borrowings, securities sold under agreements to repurchase,
	Federal Home Loan Bank advances, and other borrowings, totaled $2.152&nbsp;billion, an increase of $231.8&nbsp;million, or 12%, from December&nbsp;31, 2015. The increase in wholesale funding from December&nbsp;31, 2015 to December&nbsp;31, 2016 was
	primarily due to an increase in Federal Home Loan Bank advances. Wholesale funding as a percentage of total funding was 17% at December&nbsp;31, 2016, compared to 19% at December&nbsp;31, 2015. See Notes 14, 15, and 16 to the consolidated financial
	statements for additional details on our financing activities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following table details the average balances of all funding sources for the years
	ended December 31.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<TD COLSPAN="2" VALIGN="BOTTOM">
